title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking" in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders. Each leader appoints three members, with specific expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by Senate leaders based on expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed based on expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Appointments should consider expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, and database management. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives selects the co-chairperson. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the duration of the Commission with vacancies filled promptly. The Commission members are appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the duration of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses. The Commission members are appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve without pay but are allowed travel expenses. The Commission appointed by the President and Speaker of the House will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and incorporating outcomes measurement. The Commission will conduct a study on data infrastructure and protocols for Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on modifying data infrastructure, incorporating outcomes measurement, and creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. The Commission will study data infrastructure and protocols for Federal policymaking, including evaluating relevant administrative datasets, linking them to survey datasets, identifying barriers to data inclusion, determining data-sharing infrastructure, self-funding options for a clearinghouse, access limitations, and qualified users. The Commission will study data-sharing infrastructure, self-funding for a clearinghouse, access limitations, privacy protection, data use for program improvement, and incentives for interagency information sharing. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations on improving data accuracy and program effectiveness through interagency information sharing. The deadline for the report is 15 months after a majority of Commission members are appointed. The report, due 15 months after the majority of Commission members are appointed, will define "administrative data" as information generated by agencies for Federal programs. SEC. 5. OPERATION AND POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will receive administrative assistance from various government agencies and must convene a meeting within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members. The Commission, comprised of various government agencies, will convene a meeting within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members. The chairperson and co-chairperson will establish rules of procedure, including a quorum requirement. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. The Commission may hold hearings, contract with agencies, use the United States mails, accept gifts, and be administered by the National Academy of Public Administration. Funding is subject to availability of appropriations. The Commission may accept gifts and donations, be administered by the National Academy of Public Administration, and receive funding from principal statistical agencies not exceeding $2,000,000. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson with the concurrence of the co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services. The Commission shall terminate within 18 months of enactment.
